titleStmt.title: Duke upon duke: an excellent new play-house ballad. Set to musick by Mr. Holdecombe.
titleStmt.author: Pope, Alexander, 1688-1744.

publicationStmt.publisher: printed for A. Moor, and sold by the booksellers,

notesStmt.note: A "good part" of this ballad is ascribed to Pope by Spence on Pope's authority.
Typeset music at head of p. 1.
A satire on the quarrel between Nicholas Lechmere and Sir John Guise.
Reproduction of original from the British Library.

Electronic data. Farmington Hills, Mich. : Thomson Gale, 2003. Page image (PNG). Digitized image of the microfilm version produced in Woodbridge, CT by Research Publications, 1982-2002 (later known as Primary Source Microfilm, an imprint of the Gale Group).

Character capture and encoding have been done following the guidelines of the ECCO Text Creation Partnership, which correspond roughly to the recommendations found in Level 4 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines. Digital page images are linked to the text file.

div.p: DUKE upon DUKE, An Excellent New PLAY-HOUSE BALLAD.
Set to Muſick by Mr. HOLDECOMBE.
LONDON: Printed for A. MOOR near St. Paul's Church, and Sold by the Bookſellers. 1723. (Price Three Pence.)

div.head: DUKE upon DUKE, &c.
div.p:
〈♫〉 TO Lordings Proud I tune my SONG Who feaſt in Bow'r or Hall; 〈♫〉
〈♫〉 Tho' Dukes they be, Yet Dukes ſhall ſee, that Pride will have a 〈♫〉
〈♫〉 Fall, that Pride will have a Fall. 〈♫〉
〈♫〉
〈♫〉

lg.head: I.
lg.l: TO Lordings Proud I tune my Song,
Who Feaſt in Bow'r or Hall;
Tho' Dukes they be, yet Dukes ſhall ſee

l.hi: That Pride will have a fall.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Now that this ſame it is Right Sooth,
Full plainly doth appear;
From what befel JOHN DUKE OF GUISE,
And NIC of LANCASTERE.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: When Richard Coeur de Lyon Reign'd,
(which means a Lyon's Heart)
Like him his Barons rag'd and roar'd,
Each play'd a Lyon's Part.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: A Word and Blow was then enough,
Such Honour did them Prick,
If you but turn'd your Cheek, a Cuff,
And if your A _… e, a Kick.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Look in their Face, they tweak'd your Noſe,
At every turn fell to't;
Come near, they trode upon your Toes;
They fought from Head to Foot.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Of theſe the Duke of Lancaſtere
Stood Paramount in Pride;
He kick'd and cuff'd, and tweak'd and trode
His Foes and Friends beſide.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Firm on his Front his Beaver ſate,
So broad it hid his Chin;
For why, he thought no Man his Mate,
And fear'd to Tan his Skin.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: With Spaniſh Wool he dy'd his Cheek,
With Eſſence oyl'd his Hair;
No vixen Civet Cat more Sweet,
Nor more could Scratch and Tear.

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: Right Tall he made himſelf to ſhow,
And when all other Dukes did Bow,
This Duke did only Nod.

lg.head: X.
lg.l: Yet Courteous, Blith and Debonaire,
To GUISE's DUKE was he;
Never was ſuch a Loving Pair,
Why did they diſagree?

lg.head: XI.
lg.l: Oh! thus it was, he lov'd him dear,
And caſt how to requite him;
And having no Friend left but This,
He deem'd it meet to fight him.

lg.head: XII.
lg.l: Forthwith he drench'd his deſperate Quill,
And thus he did Indite,
This Eve at Wisk OUR SELF will Play,
Sir Duke, Be here to Night.

lg.head: XIII.
lg.l: Ah no! ah no! the Guileleſs GUISE,
Demurely did reply;

l.hi: I cannot Go, nor yet can Stand,
So ſore the Gout have I.

lg.head: XIV.
lg.l: The DUKE in Wrath call'd for his Steeds,
And fiercely drove them on;
Lord! Lord! how rattled then thy Stones,
O Kingly Kenſington!

lg.head: XV.
lg.l: All in a Trice on GUISE he ruſh'd,
Thruſt out his Lady Dear;
He tweak'd his Noſe, trod on his Toes,
And ſmote him on the Ear.

lg.head: XVI.
lg.l: But mark! how midſt of Victory
Fate ſhews an Old Dog-Trick;
Up leap'd DUKE JOHN and knock'd him down,
And ſo down fell DUKE NIC.

lg.head: XVII.
lg.l: Alaſs, Oh NIC! Oh NIC, alaſs!
Right did thy Goſſip call thee,
As who ſhould ſay, Alaſs the Day
When JOHN of GUISE ſhall maul thee.

lg.head: XVIII.
lg.l: For on thee did he clap his Chair,
And on that Chair did ſit?
And look'd as if he meant therein
To do what was not fit.

lg.head: XIX.
lg.l: Up didſt thou look, Oh woful DUKE,
Thy Mouth yet durſt not ope,
Certes, for Fear of finding there
A T _… d inſtead of Trope.

lg.head: XX.
lg.l: " Lye there thou Caitiff vile, quoth GUISE,
" No Sheet is here to ſave thee,
" The Caſememt it is ſhut likewiſe,
" Beneath my Feet I have thee.

lg.head: XXI.
lg.l: " If thou haſt ought to ſay, now ſpeak,
Then Lancaſter did cry,
" Knoweſt thou not ME, not yet thy ſelf,
" Who Thou, and WHO AM I?

lg.head: XXII.
lg.l: " Know'ſt Thou not ME, who God be prais'd,
" have bawl'd and quarell'd more
" Than all the Line of Lancaſter
" That battled heretofore?

lg.head: XXIII.
lg.l: " In Senates fam'd for many a Speech,
" And what ſome Awe muſt give Ye,
" Tho' laid thus low beneath thy Breech,
" Still of the Council Privy.

lg.head: XXIV.
lg.l: " Still of the Dutchy Chancellor,
" Durante Life I have it,
" And turn (as now thou doſt on me)
" My A _… e on thoſe that gave it.

lg.head: XXV.
lg.l: But now the Servants they ruſh'd in,
And DUKE NIC up leap'd He,

l.hi: I will not cope againſt ſuch Odds,

lg.l: But GUISE, I'll fight with Thee.

lg.head: XXVI.

l.hi: To Morrow with Thee will I fight

lg.l: No, not to Morrow, but to Night,
Quoth GUISE, I'll fight with Thee.

lg.head: XXVII.
lg.l: And now the Sun declining low,
Beſtreak'd with Blood the Skies,
When with his Sword at Saddle Bow
Rode forth the Valiant GUISE.

lg.head: XXVIII.
lg.l: Full gently praunc'd he on the Lawn,
Oft rowl'd his Eye around,
And from his Sirrup ſtretch'd to find

l.hi: Who was not to be found.

lg.head: XXIX.
lg.l: Long brandiſh'd he his Blade in Air,
Long look'd the Field all o're,
At length he ſpy'd the merry Men brown,
And eke the Coach and Four.

lg.head: XXX.
lg.l: From out the Boot bold NICHOLAS
Did wave his Hand ſo white,
As pointing out the gloomy Glade
Whereat he meant to fight.

lg.head: XXXI.
lg.l: All in that dreadful Hour ſo calm
Was Lancaſter to ſee,
As if he meant to take the Air,
Or only take a Fee.

lg.head: XXXII.
lg.l: And ſo he did, for to New Court
His trowling Wheels they run;
Not that he ſhunn'd the doubtful Strife,

lg.head: XXXIII.
lg.l: Back in the dark, by Brompton Park,
He turn'd up thro' the Gore,
So ſlunk to Campden Houſe ſo high,
All in his Coach and four.

lg.head: XXXIV.
lg.l: Mean while the GUISE did fret and fume,
A Sight it was to ſee,
Benumm'd beneath the Evening Dew,
Under the Greenwood Tree.

lg.head: XXXV.
lg.l: Then wet and weary home he far'd,
Sore mutt'ring all the Way,
The Day I meet NIC he ſhall rue
The Cudgel of that Day.

lg.head: XXXVI.
lg.l: Mean time on every piſſing Poſt
Paſte me this Recreant's Name,
So that each Piſſer-by ſhall read,
And piſs againſt the ſame.

lg.head: XXXVII.
lg.l: Now God preſerve our GRACIOUS KING,
And grant his Nobles all
May learn this Leſſon from Duke Nic,
That • Pride will have a Fall.
